title: Ananias and Apostolic Boldness
shortSummary: Acts chapter 5 recounts the sobering account of Ananias and Sapphira's deceit and sudden death, underscoring the holiness required in the early church. It also highlights the apostles’ miraculous works, their imprisonment and divine release, and their unwavering commitment to preach Jesus Christ despite opposition.
timeline: c. AD 30-33 - Early Jerusalem Church after Pentecost

keyCharacters.name: Ananias
keyCharacters.description: A member of the early church who, along with his wife, lied about the proceeds from selling land and faced divine judgment.

keyCharacters.name: Sapphira
keyCharacters.description: Wife of Ananias who conspired with him to deceive the apostles and God, resulting in her sudden death.

keyCharacters.name: Peter
keyCharacters.description: One of the leading apostles who confronts Ananias and Sapphira and boldly proclaims the gospel despite persecution.

keyCharacters.name: Gamaliel
keyCharacters.description: A respected Pharisee and teacher of the law who advises the Sanhedrin to be cautious in dealing with the apostles.

definitions.definition: The third Person of the Trinity, God’s Spirit who empowers and guides believers; here, He is grieved by Ananias' lie.

definitions.term: Tempt the Spirit of the Lord
definitions.definition: To test or challenge God’s authority and holiness by deceit or disobedience.
A Jewish sect known for denying the resurrection and opposing the apostles' teaching.
A Jewish religious leader known for strict adherence to the law; Gamaliel was a Pharisee who showed wisdom in this chapter.
A Messianic title referring to Jesus Christ’s exalted role to bring repentance and forgiveness.

outline.heading: Deceit and Judgment of Ananias and Sapphira
outline.description: Ananias and Sapphira sell land but lie about the amount given to the apostles, resulting in their immediate deaths as a divine judgment, emphasizing the seriousness of honesty before God.

outline.heading: Signs, Wonders, and Growth of the Church
outline.description: The apostles perform many miracles, leading to increased faith and growth in the number of believers, demonstrating God’s power working through them.

outline.heading: Apostles Imprisoned and Miraculously Freed
outline.description: The Sadducees arrest the apostles, but an angel frees them, commanding them to continue preaching, showing God’s sovereign protection over His messengers.

outline.heading: Confrontation with the Sanhedrin
outline.description: The apostles are brought before the Jewish council, boldly declaring obedience to God rather than men and witnessing to Jesus’ resurrection and exaltation.

outline.heading: Gamaliel’s Counsel and Apostolic Perseverance
outline.description: Gamaliel advises caution in persecuting the apostles, leading to their release; the apostles rejoice in suffering and continue daily teaching about Jesus.

application: Be honest and transparent before God and others, recognizing that deceit grieves the Holy Spirit and has serious consequences.
Trust in God’s power to protect and empower His servants even in the face of opposition and persecution.
Boldly proclaim the gospel and obey God’s commands above human authorities when there is conflict.
Rejoice in suffering for Christ’s name, knowing it is a mark of faithfulness and honor.

keyVerses.text: Then Peter and the other apostles answered and said, We ought to obey God rather than men.
keyVerses.significance: This verse affirms the principle of ultimate obedience to God’s authority over human institutions.

keyVerses.text: Him hath God exalted with his right hand to be a Prince and a Saviour, for to give repentance to Israel, and forgiveness of sins.
keyVerses.significance: It declares Jesus’ exalted role as the Messiah who grants repentance and forgiveness.

keyVerses.text: And daily in the temple, and in every house, they ceased not to teach and preach Jesus Christ.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the apostles’ steadfast commitment to evangelism and discipleship.

keyVerses.text: And great fear came upon all the church, and upon as many as heard these things.
keyVerses.significance: It shows the reverence and awe inspired by God’s holiness and judgment within the early church.
